title: How to Reuse Dead Flowers

steps.headline: Collect ingredients you'd like to use in your potpourri.
steps.description: If your dead flower arrangement is limited or unvaried in color, you can augment the color of the petals with other plants. Petals from different flowers work well, as do herbs such as rosemary, thyme, and sage. Some petals will have a stronger smell than others. For a spicier scent, try adding ingredients like cinnamon, clove, and star anise.

steps.headline: Spread the flowers out to dry.
steps.description: After gathering all your potpourri ingredients, you need to dry them thoroughly to prevent mold growth. Flowers and herbs can be laid out in a single, loose layer on a baking sheet. As long as the surface is completely smooth, it should work fine. the flowers in a dark, cool place for drying. Most flowers and herbs will be thoroughly dry after about two weeks if placed in an ideal location. To dry without rotting, the dead flowers and herbs should be placed in a location that is dry, dark, cool, and well ventilated. Ventilation is key, as it is crucial to removing moisture from the flowers and mitigating bacterial or fungal growth.

steps.headline: Add essential oils to increase the fragrance of your potpourri.
steps.description: Since essential oils dissipate quickly, you need to add a new ingredient to your potpourri mix: shavings of orris root. Use about a tablespoon (15 ml) of Orrisroot per cup (240 ml) of flower petals. You only need a few drops of each essential oil. Orris root is the root of a type of Iris, and it serves as a fixative for essential oils. The oils are absorbed into the root and slowly released into the air as fragrance. Lavender, orange blossom, and rose oil are three common types for use in potpourri, but you can select oils that suit your own taste in fragrance.

steps.headline: Mix your potpourri together.
steps.description: Once dried, place your flower petals and sprigs of herbs in a large mixing bowl. Mix the potpourri together with a spoon, folding everything gently together to avoid damaging the flowers.

steps.headline: Allow the potpourri mixture to sit for six weeks.
steps.description: Place your mixture into a glass jar or brown paper bag. Each day, shake the container a little to redistribute the ingredients. This six-week waiting period allows the essential oils to become completely and evenly absorbed by the orris root.

steps.headline: Add more flower petals and herbs to the potpourri.
steps.description: After waiting six weeks, your potpourri is ready for display. At this time, you can add more flowers and herbs if you want a mix with more volume. Your homemade potpourri can be displayed in a decorative bowl or stitched into small sachets for keeping your closet or car fresh.

steps.headline: Flatten the dead flowers before framing.
steps.description: Begin by laying the flowers between the pages of an old phone book, and then placing a heavy stack of books on top of the phone book. Leave the flowers like this for several days to flatten them out. This will be easier if the flowers have not completely withered and dried, which makes them brittle. Cull the flowers from your arrangement before they wither completely.

steps.headline: Layer the dead flowers, mat, and glass for framing.
steps.description: After pressing the flowers flat, arrange them on an uncut piece of mat board. You can use small dabs of glue to secure them if desired. Place the glass or acrylic glazing into your frame, followed by the flower arrangement on the mat board.

steps.headline: Add silica gel to protect flowers from moisture.
steps.description: To prevent the dead flowers from attracting mold or bacteria, consider placing a small packet of silica gel behind the mat board.

steps.headline: Secure the photo frame.
steps.description: Place your foam or cardboard backing into the frame and secure it. You can add glue or adhesive tape to keep it held together. Display the pressed flower art in its assembled frame wherever desired.

steps.headline: Trim the flowers to remove any excess.
steps.description: Take off any excess foliage from flowers and shape stems to your desired length. To help flowers retain color during the drying process, keep them out of the sunlight.

steps.headline: Hang the dead flowers upside-down.
steps.description: You can use string, clothespins, or tacks to secure the flowers, just make sure that they are pointed completely down.

steps.headline: Spray flowers with one light coat of hairspray.
steps.description: The hairspray will offer protection from the elements and prevent the flowers from wilting. Be sure that the hairspray used is unscented, so that the flowers’ natural scent can be preserved.

steps.headline: Leave them to dry for three days.
steps.description: Allow a few days for the flowers to dry, and, afterward, spray another thin coat of hairspray. Then, allow them to dry for one additional night.

steps.headline: Display the bouquet in a vase and enjoy.
steps.description: If you don’t have a vase, cut apart a plastic juice jug or use an empty glass bottle to hold the floral arrangement. Display your flowers on a shelf or inside a cabinet. Some flowers, such as sunflower, lotus, and poppy, have seed pods that remain once the flower has died. These flowers can be attractive to arrange in vases even after they have died.

text: Making Potpourri Collect ingredients you'd like to use in your potpourri. If your dead flower arrangement is limited or unvaried in color, you can augment the color of the petals with other plants. Petals from different flowers work well, as do herbs such as rosemary, thyme, and sage. Some petals will have a stronger smell than others. For a spicier scent, try adding ingredients like cinnamon, clove, and star anise. Spread the flowers out to dry. After gathering all your potpourri ingredients, you need to dry them thoroughly to prevent mold growth. Flowers and herbs can be laid out in a single, loose layer on a baking sheet. As long as the surface is completely smooth, it should work fine. the flowers in a dark, cool place for drying. Most flowers and herbs will be thoroughly dry after about two weeks if placed in an ideal location. To dry without rotting, the dead flowers and herbs should be placed in a location that is dry, dark, cool, and well ventilated. Ventilation is key, as it is crucial to removing moisture from the flowers and mitigating bacterial or fungal growth. Add essential oils to increase the fragrance of your potpourri. Since essential oils dissipate quickly, you need to add a new ingredient to your potpourri mix: shavings of orris root. Use about a tablespoon (15 ml) of Orrisroot per cup (240 ml) of flower petals. You only need a few drops of each essential oil. Orris root is the root of a type of Iris, and it serves as a fixative for essential oils. The oils are absorbed into the root and slowly released into the air as fragrance. Lavender, orange blossom, and rose oil are three common types for use in potpourri, but you can select oils that suit your own taste in fragrance. Mix your potpourri together. Once dried, place your flower petals and sprigs of herbs in a large mixing bowl. Mix the potpourri together with a spoon, folding everything gently together to avoid damaging the flowers. Allow the potpourri mixture to sit for six weeks. Place your mixture into a glass jar or brown paper bag. Each day, shake the container a little to redistribute the ingredients. This six-week waiting period allows the essential oils to become completely and evenly absorbed by the orris root. Add more flower petals and herbs to the potpourri. After waiting six weeks, your potpourri is ready for display. At this time, you can add more flowers and herbs if you want a mix with more volume. Your homemade potpourri can be displayed in a decorative bowl or stitched into small sachets for keeping your closet or car fresh. Creating a Pressed Flower Artwork Flatten the dead flowers before framing. Begin by laying the flowers between the pages of an old phone book, and then placing a heavy stack of books on top of the phone book. Leave the flowers like this for several days to flatten them out. This will be easier if the flowers have not completely withered and dried, which makes them brittle. Cull the flowers from your arrangement before they wither completely. Layer the dead flowers, mat, and glass for framing. After pressing the flowers flat, arrange them on an uncut piece of mat board. You can use small dabs of glue to secure them if desired. Place the glass or acrylic glazing into your frame, followed by the flower arrangement on the mat board. Add silica gel to protect flowers from moisture. To prevent the dead flowers from attracting mold or bacteria, consider placing a small packet of silica gel behind the mat board. Secure the photo frame. Place your foam or cardboard backing into the frame and secure it. You can add glue or adhesive tape to keep it held together. Display the pressed flower art in its assembled frame wherever desired. Preserving Flowers as a Bouquet Trim the flowers to remove any excess. Take off any excess foliage from flowers and shape stems to your desired length. To help flowers retain color during the drying process, keep them out of the sunlight. Hang the dead flowers upside-down. You can use string, clothespins, or tacks to secure the flowers, just make sure that they are pointed completely down. Spray flowers with one light coat of hairspray. The hairspray will offer protection from the elements and prevent the flowers from wilting. Be sure that the hairspray used is unscented, so that the flowers’ natural scent can be preserved. Leave them to dry for three days. Allow a few days for the flowers to dry, and, afterward, spray another thin coat of hairspray. Then, allow them to dry for one additional night. Display the bouquet in a vase and enjoy. If you don’t have a vase, cut apart a plastic juice jug or use an empty glass bottle to hold the floral arrangement. Display your flowers on a shelf or inside a cabinet. Some flowers, such as sunflower, lotus, and poppy, have seed pods that remain once the flower has died. These flowers can be attractive to arrange in vases even after they have died.
